details: Root folder
This contains all of drupal core except for things that must be in the root, like index.php etc. Generally, you shouldn't need to be adding/editing/removing anything in here.
The directory into which all downloaded and custom modules go. Splitting this up into the sub-directories "contrib" and "custom" can make it easier to keep track of the modules.
Contains downloaded and custom installation profiles. Installation profiles are generally provided as part of a Drupal distribution.

Site-specific files tend to go here. This could be files uploaded by users, such as images, but also includes the configuration, active as well as staged config. The configuration is read and written by Drupal and should have the minimal amount of privileges required for the web server, and the only the web server, to read and modify them.
Contains downloaded and custom themes. This directory separates downloaded and custom themes from Drupal core's themes. This allows Drupal core to be updated without overwriting these files.
Backend libraries that Drupal Core depends on. (Symfony, Twig, etc).
Includes the autoloader created by Composer.
You can list the dependencies of the project in this file and running composer install will download the dependencies.
This file locks the dependencies of your project to a known state. This file is generated automatically.

This file contains default .gitignore rules. To use it, copy it to .gitignore, and it will cause files like your settings.php and user-uploaded files to be excluded from Git version control. This is a common strategy to avoid accidentally including private information in public repositories and patch files.
The PHP page that serves all page requests on a Drupal installation.

This file is to prevent the crawling and indexing of certain parts of your site by web crawlers and spiders run by sites like Yahoo! and Google. By telling these "robots" where not to go on your site, you save bandwidth and server resources.
The PHP page that handles updating the Drupal installation.
Server configuration file.
Various external libraries used by Core (includes jQuery, underscore, modernizer, etc.)
Frontend code that Drupal Core depends on.
Functionality that is to low level to be modular. Such as the module system itself.
Drupal Core classes.
Drupal Core modules.
Drupal Core installation profiles. Minimal, Standard, Testing and Testing multilingual installation profiles by default.
Various CLI scripts, mostly used by developers.
Drupal Core tests.
Drupal Core themes.
Custom theme folder.
Contains CSS files.
Contains fonts used in the custom theme.
Contains images.
Contains common template files that can be reused.
Contains scripts files.
Template files to override the basic templates.
Logo of the custom theme.
This file stores metadata about the custom theme. It notifies Drupal about the existence of a module, theme, or install profile.
This file is used to add any kind of assets (CSS or JavaScript) to the page.
Contains functions to support theming in the custom theme.
